sentences.english: There was a rich man who was clothed in purple and fine linen and who feasted sumptuously every day.
sentences.chinese: 有一個財主穿著紫色袍和細麻布衣服，天天奢華宴樂。

sentences.english: And they drank， and were merry with him.
sentences.chinese: 他們就飲酒，和約瑟一同宴樂。

sentences.english: But she who lives in pleasure is dead while she lives.
sentences.chinese: 但那好宴樂的寡婦正活著的時候也是死的。

sentences.english: Thou shalt not also go into the house of feasting, to sit with them to eat and to drink.
sentences.chinese: 你不可進入宴樂的家，與他們同坐喫喝。

sentences.english: In the day of our king the princes have made him sick with bottles of wine;
sentences.chinese: 在我們王宴樂的日子，首領因酒的烈性成病。

sentences.english: It is not fitting for a fool to live in luxury- how much worse for a slave to rule over princes!
sentences.chinese: 愚昧人宴樂度日，是不合宜的，何況僕人管轄王子呢？

sentences.english: Delight is not seemly for a fool; much less for a servant to have rule over princes.
sentences.chinese: 愚昧人宴樂度日，是不合宜的，何況僕人管轄王子呢。

definition: to reach everywhere/to stop at nothing/to do one's utmost
to be content with poverty and strive for virtue (idiom)
Deng Tong (2nd c. BC), one of the wealthiest Former Han Dynasty 前漢|前汉[Qian2 Han4] officials
booklet/brochure/(old) book (made of bamboo strips tied together)
Huailai county in Zhangjiakou 張家口|张家口[Zhang1 jia1 kou3], Hebei
street name in ancient Chang'an synonymous with brothel area/red-light district
bridal room and ornamented candles/wedding festivities (idiom)
to hold a lamp/to light a lamp
